quoteFirst: After a few hours' rest, Junius set off again to rejoin his companion, being accompanied by Hepburn, who was directed to remain about two miles above the fall, to arrest the canoes on their passage, lest we should too suddenly surprise the Esquimaux.
quoteLast: we were mortified by the appearance of the Indians with Mr. Wentzel, who had in vain endeavoured to restrain them from following us.
title: Narrative of a Journey to the Shores of the Polar Sea, in the years 1819-20-21-22, Volume 2
author: Franklin, John, 1786-1847

quoteFirst: He reached his destination without mishap, and went back to Sunny Hills that night. He had some difficulty in finding the place, stopping as the girls had, at the airport to inquire, and reaching the Stillman estate
title: Linda Carlton, Air Pilot
author: Lavell, Edith

quoteFirst: The mails take fifty-six hours to do this distance, though they too are supposed to go through without stopping; but Pater did the 254 miles in thirty-three hours, to every one’s great astonishment, as that “beats the record” by a good deal. They would even have done it in less time, only in the night, when they must all have been dozing (it was
quoteLast: , and they had been in the carriage _then_ for nineteen hours!), they drove into a waggon slowly creeping along the road. You may suppose what a terrible crash they made, doing no great harm, however, except to one wheel; fortunately they were only a mile or so from the post-house, so they were able to get another trap and come on directly.
title: Letters to Guy
author: Barker, Lady (Mary Anne), 1831-1911

quoteFirst: Both the combatants were pinioned and confined; at length tranquillity and order were restored, but for a short time only.
quoteLast: the most horrible screams issued from the prison, to which place I immediately proceeded accompanied by Captain Brown. We soon came to the place where the disturbance was going forward, and found Sarah Downes and Elizabeth Cheatham both nearly exhausted from a battle in which they had just been engaged.
title: Two Voyages to New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land
author: Reid, Thomas, 1791-1825

quoteFirst: At two places in the sea the steamer seems as though she would surely go on the rocks in the narrow channel, but the pilot swings her almost within her own length and she turns again into a wider arm of the sea. In these narrow channels the tide runs like a mill race, and without a pilot (who knows every current) any vessel would be in extreme danger. The steamer leaves Kobe
quoteLast: and reaches Nagasaki, the most western of Japanese cities, about seven o'clock the following morning.
title: The Critic in the Orient
author: Fitch, George Hamlin, 1852-1925

quoteFirst: During our preparations the ships themselves stood towards the port with all the sail they could make, being secure that we were yet at too great a distance to be seen. But
quoteLast: , the ships being then within five leagues of the place, Lieutenant Brett, with the boats under his command, put off, and arrived at the mouth of the bay without being discovered; but no sooner had he entered it than some of the people on board a vessel riding at anchor there perceived him, who instantly put off in their boat, rowing towards the fort, shouting and crying, "The English! the English dogs!" by which the whole town was suddenly alarmed; and our people soon observed several lights hurrying backwards and forwards in the fort and other marks of the inhabitants being in great
title:
Anson's Voyage Round the World
The Text Reduced
author: Walter, Richard, 1716?-1785; Household, H. W. [Commentator]

quoteLast: ," and there, in a few minutes, put an end to it. We took Penruddock, Grove, and long lists of others; Wagstaff unluckily escaped ...
title: The Quarterly Review, Volume 162, No. 324, April, 1886
author: Various

quoteFirst: There was a supper at the Vatican. Alfonso made an elegant toilet, and
quoteLast: prepared to go from the quarters he inhabited into those where the pope lived; but the door which separated the two courts of the building was shut, and knock as he would, no one came to open it. Alfonso then thought that it was a simple matter for him to go round by the Piazza of St.
title:
The Borgias
Celebrated Crimes
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870

quoteLast: that it became increasingly evident that youth was paying with a vengeance.  The persuasive gentleman had a very considerable proportion of the total number of chips beside him, to say nothing of a small library of written chits.
title: The Man in Ratcatcher, and Other Stories
author: McNeile, H. C. (Herman Cyril), 1888-1937

quoteLast: , as the admiral was in the great cabin, he saw a light on shore, but said it was so obscure that he could not affirm it to be land, though he called Pedro Gutierrez, and bid him observe whether he saw the light, who said he did. Shortly afterward they called Rodrigo Sanchez, of Segovia, to look that way, but he could not see it, because he did not come in time to the place where it might have been seen.
title: The Discoveries of America to the Year 1525
author: Weise, Arthur James, 1838-1921

quoteFirst: No, no; one of them has promised to come back to take my place in a couple of hours; then I'll go out as if to sport, and mark out our way across the country. I shall come on again to watch
quoteLast: , and then, depend upon it, they'll all be drinking as hard as they can drink, till they go to bed. Most of them will be drunk; and, when they are all fast asleep, we can do what we will, for Franklin Gray won't be back till noon to-morrow, so you and I, and Harriet here, can take horses and be off.
title: The Robber, A Tale.
author: James, G. P. R. (George Payne Rainsford), 1801?-1860

quoteLast: , I was serving Mr. Riach and the captain at their supper, when the ship struck something with a great sound, and we heard voices singing out. My two masters leaped to their feet.
title:
Kidnapped (Illustrated)
Being Memoirs of the Adventures of David Balfour in the Year 1751
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis, 1850-1894; Wyeth, N. C. (Newell Convers), 1882-1945 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: Hart come down to the Forest Queen looking pale and haggard, and he was that broke up he had to get three drinks in him before he could say a word. Everybody was so interested, wanting to hear what he had to tell 'em, he didn't need to ask to have the game stopped--it just stopped of its own accord.
title:
Santa Fé's Partner
Being Some Memorials of Events in a New-Mexican Track-end Town
author: Janvier, Thomas A. (Thomas Allibone), 1849-1913

quoteLast: ; the moon rode high in the heavens, which were flecked here and there by small patches of fleecy scurrying cloud; the fog had drifted away, leaving the atmosphere delightfully pure and clear, so that, narrow as was the channel down which we were winding our way, we had no difficulty in steering clear of all obstruction.
title: The Rover's Secret: A Tale of the Pirate Cays and Lagoons of Cuba
author: Collingwood, Harry, 1851-1922; Symons, William Christian, 1845-1911 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Larin, who was very tired after the journey and patently conscious that Radek was a formidable opponent, made a speech setting out his reasons for differing with the Central Committee, and proposed an ingenious resolution, which, while expressing approval of the general position of the Committee, included four supplementary modifications which, as a matter of fact, nullified that position altogether. It was then
quoteLast: , and the Conference adjourned. We drove round to the prison in sledges, and by way of supper had some more soup and potatoes, and so back to the railway station to sleep in the cars.
title: The Crisis in Russia
author: Ransome, Arthur, 1884-1967

quoteFirst: The packet carried me back there
quoteLast: , and, having no freight, only touched to let me off. My boats were on one end of the well-built landing wharf paralleling the river, and now at the other end was a little schooner of perhaps two hundred tons burden.
title: Fighting Byng: A Novel of Mystery, Intrigue and Adventure
author: Stone, A.; Bird, Leslie Pern [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Meanwhile the Thirty-sixth and the other regiments of Morrison's brigade remained on the Kingston road in front of Lenoir's. The enemy, anticipating an evacuation of the place, made an attack on our lines
quoteLast: ; but a few shots from our pickets were sufficient to satisfy him that we still held the ground. Additional pickets, however, were sent out to extend the line held by the Eighth Michigan.
title: History of the Thirty-sixth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers. 1862-1865
author: Burrage, Henry S. (Henry Sweetser), 1837-1926; Hodgkins, William H. (William Henry), 1840-1905; Noyes, Edmund W.; Ranlett, S. Alonzo; White, Alonzo A.

quoteFirst: Hegarty was to expect the arrival of an officer of the I.R.A. in uniform, who would come from the direction of Castleport on a bicycle
quoteLast: Hegarty was to keep this officer in his house, place the new supply of American arms at his disposal for ambushes, and the officer would not leave the district until Blake had been either killed or kidnapped.
title: Tales of the R.I.C.
author: Unknown [Adapter]

quoteLast: the deputies[86] returned, and brought a letter in answer to the message sent by them.
title:
The Jacobite Rebellions (1689-1746)

quoteFirst: Don Rodrigo de Mendoça was the commander. He insisted upon an immediate attack by night, saying that "any two of his ships could take all England, and much more these hens of Holland, who must be spent and wasted by so long a voyage."
quoteLast: , the Spanish admiral and the Dutch admiral closed,--the Jesu Maria and the Great Sun. They hailed each other, and some conversation passed before a shot was fired.
title:
Ocean's Story; or, Triumphs of Thirty Centuries
Maritime Adventures, Achievements, Explorations, Discoveries and Inventions; and of the Rise and Progress of Ship-Building and Ocean Navigation, from the Ark to the Iron Steamships
author: Goodrich, Frank B. (Frank Boott), 1826-1894; Howland, Edward [Contributor]
